ratings.question_text: What percentage of the reading and other assignments did you complete?

narratives.question_text: How well was the course organized?
comments: This is Caitie - I would rate this as "excellent" in terms of the content. I only lowered my rating to "good" due to a few times when we had somewhat last-minute (i.e., less than a week) messages about what to prepare for the next week's class. There are certain weeks when I know that my homework hours are going to be tight, and I am disciplined about planning for these weeks in advance / doing work as much in advance as possible. Knowing the specific episodes, as well as having the PDFs of / links to the plays 2 weeks+ ahead of time (and not having plays removed at the last-minute) would have been helpful for me. I am probably unusual in this regard, but thought I'd mention it!
I liked that the course went in chronological order and eventually switched over into contemporary film and television.

narratives.question_text: How effective was the balance between instruction and discussion?
comments: This is Caitie - I appreciated that Catherine would usually open the class with a stimulating, overarching lecture on that week's topic, and then open it up to discussion for the bulk of the class (inserting mini lectures as relevant). This worked great for me, as I gleaned much from my classmates, and as I enjoyed sharing my experiences of the works. Satire is, as I have learned, a social medium!

I thought the class had a great balance of instruction and discussion. At times the environment felt a bit intimidating to us non-dramaturgy students, but the instructor was very conscious of soliciting everyone's opinion.

Catherine Sheehy is just a total badass. She weaves seamlessly between instruction, opinion, tangential thought that actually totally illuminates something, and seeking her students' responses. She sets the intellectual tone of a room very high without making anyone feel stupid. It's thrilling and funny and challenging and stimulating.

narratives.question_text: How well did the assigned papers, reports or other projects reflect the aims of the course?
comments: This is Caitie - I LOVED the opportunity to write my own satire, and was glad that we were given an early heads-up about this on the first day. At first, I was hesitant to take on the challenge, but the more time I had to brainstorm potential topics and forms, the more I got excited about the prospect, until one day my satire idea popped fully formed in my head and I began to put figurative pen to paper, with enough time to write in 2-hour spurts over the course of a few weeks.

The assigned writing project elevated my understanding of the material by asking me to apply concepts that were examined in class to works outside of the classroom. It really tested my understanding of the concepts but also allowed for me to interpret the concepts with respect to the specific pieces I chose to write about.

I audited this course, so I didn't write the assigned final paper -- BUT if I had, I probably would have taken the option to write an original satire. I love that this option was offered as an alternative to an academic paper (it would have been equally challenging, if not much more so, and a whole lot of fun).

narratives.question_text: How did the amount of assigned reading work with weekly discussion?
comments: This is Caitie - I was appreciative that Catherine pushed us to read / watch a lot of content. She reminded us often that we had a lot to prepare for the next week (and got specific about any exceptional weeks). I got so much out of the course due in large part to the sheer volume of material we covered. And I am really glad that we took on 2-hour classes every week, rather than fewer weeks of 3-hour classes. It was also very generous of Catherine to come in every morning to screen episodes an hour before class, as an optional add-on for us. I was usually able to catch the last episode screened each morning, and it was a great way to start off each class.
It was a lot of reading. I think this is typical for dramaturgy but it was much more than I've had to do for any other class as a non-dramaturgy student.

I felt that the amount of assigned reading was beyond what I could realistically accomplish given my other YSD commitments. At times I was disappointed that I couldn't participate in discussion to the fullest extent because I hadn't had time to complete all the reading assignments.

There were definitely classes when you could tell that not everyone -- myself included -- had done all the reading. It was a lot. But it's a huge and fascinating topic and, honestly, I wouldn't recommend there be less reading. Sometimes we have to skim or skip and that's not great, but it still introduces us to the widest possible array of awesome literature. So yeah, lots of reading, but you know, it's up to us to get our butts in gear and deal with it.

This is Caitie - the TV and film content was incredible. I never appreciated shows like Arrested Development before, because I had never been able to get through more than one or two episodes before giving up. Hilarious, I used to call shows like this "too Flintstones-y" because I would get frustrated when the characters would get into more and more trouble due to mind-numbing levels of stupidity. Same goes for Ali G, and I never even tried Bob's Burgers, etc. Now, I have developed an appreciation for this kind of satire, and the message it is conveying. It's more about the subject of the satire, not the seemingly annoying characters, who are actually well-loved by the creator (and, now, by me!).
Knowing the assigned episodes before the weekend helped my time management.
The supplementary materials were as important as the reading. I really loved the opportunity to watch videos in the 9-10am slot on Thursdays.

SUCH great discussion of film and television in this class. Especially since TV is becoming such a fertile medium for good writers and actors these days, it was great to have a class that really engaged with smart contemporary media.

narratives.question_text: The course filled a significant gap in your knowledge of the field.
comments: This is Caitie - Yes; see my previous answer re: supplementary materials.
Now I want MORE satire.

narratives.question_text: Regardless of whether or not the course is required, would you recommend it to other students in and outside the department?
comments: This is Caitie - absolutely. Although it is only offered every 3 years I believe, so I think I will have to save my recommendation for future generations?

Yes. Given that I'm from an outside department that requires a dramaturgy elective, I would absolutely recommend this course to others in my situation. It's very accessible to newcomers to in-depth dramaturgical analysis.
Absolutely.
Yes.
Yes
Yes, the course was filled with great discussions and a lot of laughs.
yes
Yes, definitely. Or anything Catherine Sheehy teaches.

narratives.question_text: The course goals were clearly presented.
comments: This is Caitie - I really appreciated Catherine's big-picture reminders each class about this genre and what it was / is meant to accomplish.

narratives.question_text: The instructor has a strong grasp of the course subject matter.
comments: This is Caitie - unquestionably, and re: all types of satire (ancient, contemporary British, contemporary American, etc.). We focused on the latter two due to the need for satire to be "of the moment" in order for it to be effective, and it was a bit harder for us to "get" the older satire. Though Catherine did an excellent job of putting the older works into context for us.
Catherine's breadth and depth of knowledge is astounding.
Uh, like, the STRONGEST.

narratives.question_text: The instructor presented the subject matter effectively.
comments: This is Caitie - Catherine is both incredibly insightful and wildly entertaining.

narratives.question_text: The instructor was willing to consider diverse points of view.
comments: This is Caitie - yes, although she did not hesitate to refine or contradict a student's comment if it was a bit off-base. Trying to think of examples ... maybe with some of Rachel's comments?

narratives.question_text: The instructor was willing to answer pertinent questions.
comments: This is Caitie - yes, and I had lots of them! Catherine was great at helping me understand why I wasn't liking certain characters, and helping me grow to appreciate their function / their creators' true love of them.

narratives.question_text: The grading criteria was clearly explained.
comments: This is Caitie - yep, very clear. Show up prepared, participate, and the final.
Again, I was auditing, but Catherine was super clear at the very start of the class as to how the grading would work. No problems there.

narratives.question_text: The instructor was available for consultation, discussion and advice.
comments: This is Caitie - yes, Catherine reminded us early and often that we could reach out anytime with questions, particularly re: the final.
I never asked, but my guess is she totally would have been. She's super prompt at answering emails!

narratives.question_text: I would recommend this instructor to other students.
comments: This is Caitie - yes, who wouldn't?!
ALWAYS.

narratives.question_text: How many of the 14 class meetings did you attend?  Comments:
comments: This is Caitie - all 14.
13. 1 excused absence.
All
All 14 meetings.
I missed two. One for illness and one to see the Shakespeare Quartets.

narratives.question_text: Please offer additional comments you have on such topics as: what worked best about the course, what improvements you would suggest, etc.
comments: This is Caitie - I have tried to be pretty comprehensive and specific in the above, so I have nothing else to add! A fantastic course and professor. Has changed the way I read / watch satire!!
